lines.content: * The {@code lict.DateTime} class handles date and time information, allowing for flexible input of either date only or both date and time.
* It provides methods to format the date and time for display and data storage purposes.
* Constructs a {@code lict.DateTime} object by parsing the provided string, which can be in the format "yyyy-MM-dd" or "yyyy-MM-dd HHmm".
* Depending on the format, it initializes either a {@code LocalDate} or a {@code LocalDateTime}.
* @param info The date or date and time information as a string.
* @throws DateTimeException if the input string does not match the expected formats.
* Returns the formatted string representation of the date or date-time.
* The format used depends on whether the object was initialized with a date only or both date and time.
* @return A string representing the formatted date or date-time.
* Returns the formatted string suitable for data storage, representing the date or date-time.
* The format will match the input format used to initialize the object.
* @return A string formatted for data storage representing the date or date-time.

* It loads tasks from the specified file path.
* @param filePath The file path where the task data is stored.

* The {@code TaskList} class manages a list of {@code Task} objects.

* Displays a separator line for clarity in the console output.
* Displays an error message in the console.
* @param message The error message to display.
* Displays the list of tasks currently in the task list.
* @param tasks The task list containing the tasks to display.
System.out.println("There are no tasks in your list.");
System.out.println("Here are the tasks in your list:");
* Displays a list of tasks that match the given keyword filter.
* This method searches through the provided task list for tasks that contain the specified keyword
* and displays them. If no tasks match the keyword or if the keyword is empty, a message indicating
* that no matching tasks were found will be displayed.
* @param tasks  The list of tasks to be searched and filtered.
* @param filter The keyword to filter the tasks by. If the filter is empty, all tasks will be considered as non-matching.
public void showFilteredTasks(TaskList tasks, String filter) {
System.out.println("There are no tasks in your list that matches the keyword '" + filter + "'.");
System.out.println("There are no tasks in your list that matches the keyword '" + filter + "'.");
System.out.println("Here are the matching tasks in your list:");

System.out.println("Nice! I've marked this task as done:");
* Displays a message indicating that a task has been marked as not done.
* @param t The task that has been marked as not done.
System.out.println("OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:");

* Ends the conversation with the user by displaying a goodbye message and closing the scanner.

* The abstract {@code Command} class represents a command that can be executed in the application.
* Subclasses of {@code Command} must implement the {@code execute} method to define the specific behavior of the command.
* Returns whether the command is an exit command.
* By default, commands do not exit the application, so this method returns {@code false}.
* Subclasses can override this method if they represent exit commands.
* @return {@code false} by default, indicating the application should not exit.
* Executes the command, performing the necessary operations on the task list, UI, and storage.
* This method must be implemented by subclasses to define specific command behavior.
* @param tasks   The task list on which the command operates.
* @param ui      The UI component for displaying messages to the user.
* @param storage The storage component for saving changes to the task list.
* @throws LictException If an error occurs during command execution.
public abstract void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws LictException;
